reviews.review: I love this game and would recomend it to anyone. Especialy the puzzle loving group of people.

You like mind games, sci-fi, robots, puzzle and you have friends? you better try this game! 
play alone when you're lonely or play with friends for a different map settings.

The co-op play need cooperation, cooperation, cooperation, cooperation and cooperation to get out of the current level.

You can try trolling too! Yep! you can troll your partner! and do high-five!

10/10

Testé uniquement en solo (il y a une partie coop à deux)

La campagne est bien menée, il y a bien sûr des chambres de tests mais on se promène aussi pas mal comme dans une "aventure".

Les enigmes ne sont pas trop compliquées (mais on est pas du tout pris en main), avec un peu de réflexion et quelques essais on y arrive en général assez vite. La dextérité est parfois nécessaire mais vraiment rien d'infaisable. La mise en scene est bien vu, comme on a pas d'indices sur ce qu'il faut faire dans certain endroits il faut essayer de comprendre où aller et par quelle(s) route(s), mais avec un peu d'observation et d'habitude on progresse assez vite.

L'humour est bien présent et les clins d'oeils egalement, on retrouve avec plaisir la société APERTURE et ses robots déjantés ainsi que les voix qui nous accompagne.

Constitué de 10 Chapitres pour la campagne solo (bouclée en 8 heures, le dernier étant un combat final plutôt facile), le jeu à une bonne durée de vie pour ceux qui exploiterons en plus toutes les possibilités : solo + coop + tests du workshop en solo ou coop.

A recommander et souvent en bundle en promo.

Итак...портал 2...портал...лучше или нет...
Ну типа токого вопроса я себе задал когда устанавливал эту игру,и что же я про неё могу сказать...Ну а то что к названию надо было приписать 2х,так как во второй части помножили сюжет на 2,а тоесть сначала мы также проходим комнаты испытаний,побеждаем ГЛаДОС,а потом блуждаем по сторому аппертур и также по совместительству проходим испытания,ну и вконце концов побеждаем ублюдка и...хеппи энд(ну как хеппи энд,есть продолжение,где это совсем не хеппи энд)
Гемплей состоит из решения головоломок,ну и естественно тут произошли изменения,ведь теперь добавили гелик,ну а также кубы отражающие лазеры...и..кубы-монстры(неудачный эксперемент так сказать)
Также добавили кооп,которым можно назвать доп. сюжетом,правда я его не смог заценить,так как я не имею друзей задротов,точнее имею,но один играет в майн,второй в самп(ему этот портал вообще не сдался),ну а третий профукал библиотеку и у него нет денег,да и усугубляет эту ситуацию отсутствие микрофона
Ну и последние добавление это создание карт от сообщества,то есть теперь вы можите пройти карту друга или он вашу,ну и естественно карты других пользователей
Определённо если вам было недостаточно первого портала,то этого вам ТОЧНО хватит надолго

I'm pretty late to the party, and since everything that can be said about this game has already been said, I'll just add my own 2 cents to the review.

The storytelling is excellent. Plot twists are practically sitting behind every corner, and you never know where the story is going to go next. It has amazing pacing, very memorable and lovable characters, and an overall great atmosphere.

The score adds a certain ambiance to the levels that completely enhanced the experience of the game. In fast-paced chase sections, the soft, futuristic music transforms into a high tempo chase theme matching the gameplay. The composers definitely stepped up the game in this department.

Where the game falls short, however, is the gameplay. Unlike the first game where it's just you, the portal gun, cubes and buttons, this game tried too hard with the gimmicks, whether it be the light walls, gels, or the gravity fields. Sure, some of the rooms had me stuck for a couple of minutes, but none of the new mechanics introduce puzzles truly challenging.

Between the memorable storyline / characeters, Co-op mode, and the workshop allowing the creation of your own  levels and testing others' levels, I would still highly recommend this game to just about anyone. 7.5/10
Here we are again, it's always such a pleasure.

传送门2，多年前朋友推荐给我的老游戏了，现在通关了后悔为什么当年没玩！
脑洞很大的游戏，在传送门1的基础上开发了更新鲜的激光、跳板、光桥、特殊涂料……等等超多的新玩法和关卡，后面谜题越来越难，真正地感受到了烧脑的快感！有的时候感觉自己快要坚持不住去查攻略了，但坚持了一下最终还是解开了谜题，我跟你讲，这种感觉，就像多年便秘突然好了一样爽！（噫
剧情方面也相当优秀，很好的塑造了一个智障和一个粉切黑的形象，还好好地黑了一把万恶的资本主义。以及有时候glaDOS的吐槽太犀利了好吗！这毒舌人外的设定！（噫
游戏中还夹杂了不少小彩蛋，很有趣，通关动画也让人菊花一紧。
多人游戏目前还没玩过，但我觉得单机模式就已经足够好了。

Few sequels face as daunting a legacy to live up to as Portal 2. The original stands as one of the cleverest and most revered games ever made and so the pressure is on for the return visit to Aperture Laboratories.

As before, you play a human lab rat subjected to the experimental challenges dreamt up by the evil computer GLaDOS. The goal is to exit ever more puzzling rooms with the aid of a Portal Gun that lets you shoot up to two virtual doorways onto walls coated with a special substance. Once you've got two portals in place you can walk through one and come out of the other.

Initially the challenges thrown at you are straightforward: zap one portal onto the wall next to you, put the other onto the wall next to the inaccessible exit and then simply walk through the portal. But after a few gentle introductory tests to familiarise you with the concept, Portal 2 starts presenting you with brain-aching challenge after brain-aching challenge.

You might need to open an exit by placing a block on a pressure pad, but the block is located on an inaccessible ledge high above you with no obvious route up. To reach it might involve using portals to reach a high walkway before firing a portal into the floor below and the other into the wall opposite the ledge with the block, so that when you jump down into the portal on the floor you are sent flying out of the other portal and onto the ledge with the block.

And soon the complexity is cranked up with the addition of other elements to the puzzles such as tractor beams, gels that alter the properties of surfaces and bridges made out of light.

Like many puzzle games the description often sounds more intimidating than the reality, but Portal 2's environmental conundrums are truly challenging: requiring lateral thinking and dissolving notions of up, down, left, right, forward and back. But while the challenges can be bewildering, the sense of achievement you get from solving a challenge that had you stumped is immense with confusion melting away into a thrilling Eureka! moment.

Portal 2's fiendish puzzles would make a great game on their own, but the game doesn't compromise on setting either, moulding a captivating story out of its puzzling action. The script and voice acting is nothing short of fantastic: the acidic wit of superb*tch GLaDOS balanced by the bumbling Bristolian tones of Stephen Merchant, who plays an equally amusing rival AI.

Beyond the single-player mode there's a set of co-operative two-player challenges that can be played in split screen or online. The two-player challenges are even tougher than the single player so the need to discuss with each other how to tackle each puzzle is paramount. While this means it works best when players are in the same room, Valve have done a sterling job of providing players with tools to indicate their ideas to other players so that the online mode works almost as well.

The only possible criticism you could level at the game is that once a room is solved, there's little reason to go back. But when a game delivers as many moments of joy and satisfaction as Portal 2, you'll need to be a rather sour soul to make such a charge.

Ingenious, engrossing puzzler and a worthy sequel to one of the greatest games ever!

Portal 2 is quite possibly my favourite video game of all time. There is no excuse as to why someone should not wish to play it, other than perhaps that they have not played the first game. It is witty, funny, story-rich, beautiful, atmospheric, with phenomenal art and amazing game mechanics. It is a puzzle game, however the main focus of the game isn't to challenge you so hard that the puzzles are near-impossible. While they somewhat increase in difficulty as the game progresses, the focus of the game continues to be the story it is telling. And the beautifully crafted dialogue along with the subtleties and easter eggs peppered along the game deliver a story that is both deep and not obvious. The theories and ideas that spring from what you find make you realise that the Portal story is a lot more than what you can scrape off of the surface of the game.

The game mechanics themselves work wonderfully - most first person shooters which lack a 'run' button would be infuriating and tedious, however the speed at which Chell moves and the context in which she is moving do not leave you annoyed at the lack of such a function. The simplicity of operating the gun is unmatched to the wonderful things you can do with it. The handling feels comfortable, and the sound design to go along with it makes the whole experience feel just right.

The soundtrack alone is enough to convince someone to want to play it. Sometimes electronic, sometimes glitchy, sometimes heavy with percussion, sometimes orchestral.. Whatever it is at the specific moment in the game, it sounds good. It sounds epic and immersive, and it gives you exactly what feelings you need to have to suit the part of the game you're playing.

The co-operative campaign is fun as well, and despite not being particularly 'story rich' (which, really, co-op doesn't need to be), the context of the co-op campaign is related to the single player story, which makes it feel relevant, as opposed to a random add-on just for the sake of it. There is a challenge there, and it does genuinely require the two players to work together. It can be completed in a matter of hours, but they're not hours in vain - the co-op is genuinely fulfulling and a lot of fun. And, in typical Valve tradition, doesn't take itself too seriously.

As a great fan of Portal 1 this game was a bit of a disapointment for me. The puzzles are no challenge if you are familiar with thinking in portals and all in all the level design is often spoiling the solution. Sometimes I solved rooms only by shooting a portal on the only spot the game let me without me even seeing the consequences beforehand. Thus the most difficult rooms were those where i thought "Finally, this seems like the first difficult one" with me ending up overthinking the dullest solution. During the finally the game even limits your camera movement pushing your face right into the solution of the only real puzzle of the whole boss fight.
I was seeing forward to the steam workshop levels but this is ruined by the weak rating system as it is only possible to rate a level "good" or "bad" resulting in average levels having a maximum rating. I ended up downrating quite lovely levels only because they were a bit to easy.

The story and enviromental design feels a bit rushed and often does not make sense. Infact it often feels like a alternative version of the original Portal's story, no twist beeing really surprising. The strength of Portal 1 was its atmosphere delivered by a few objects and wallpaintings here and there which had nothing to do with the actual test chambers and had to be discovered by the player himself. In Portal 2 you do not feel near as isolated while the game constantly tries to make you feel that way.

All in all Portal 2 ends up spoiling it's own puzzles and poorly trying to mimic the esthetics of the original Portal. You can see in which aspects of the game the devs put the most effort but it is not enough to make a good atmosphere or a good puzzle game
